properties.name: Almost Killed Me
properties.description: Posted by GordoThe South Jetty A seemingly great place to come, watch enormous waves rush in to the channel of the bay, and well, ... get yourself killed. One cold February morning in 1983 I came out to the end of the jetty with my cousin Warren and watched enormous waves, reported to be 24- 28 feet tall, roll right in to the bay. Until, that is one crashed in to the jetty and knocked me down and dragged me towards the sharp dolos and rocks that surround the end of the jetty. My advice. View this place from a safe distance. I can still taste the saltwater on cold mornings.

properties.name: Cannibals?!?!
properties.description: Posted by GordoCannibal Island\'s West CoastThe western end of Cannibal Island Road meets the Eel River and overlooks the mouth of the river. A charming place for a sunset viewing, a dance by moonlight to a car radio, or a chance to view shelves of dark clay and beach sand mingled by the forces of tide and river.

properties.name: Centerville Beach
properties.description: Posted by Gordo  Centerville Beach ParkingAn often unpopulated beach that stretches for MILES to the north, Ending at the south side of the mouth of the Eel River. Look to the east when you get to the northernmost stretch and you can see Cannibal Island.

properties.name: Channel of the Bay
properties.description: Posted by GordoThe Channel of Humboldt BayThe channel entry of Humboldt Bay. When the waves are at their most heinous gnarly Surfer Dudes and Chicks come and ride in defiance of the sharp barnacle encrusted boulders and dolos that the Army Corp of Engineers used to build the artificial extension of the bay out in to the ocean. Siteseers standing along the edges risk being pummeled, splashed, swept away and amazed by the force of the enormous swells and waves that crash in to, and over the seawall. On more traquil days there are all sorts of small craft plying the waters.

properties.name: Mad River Slough Kayak Put In.
properties.description: Posted by GordoThe Mad River Slough at Hwy 255Between the defunct railroad trestle and the hwy bridge that crosses the Mad River Slough is a great place to put in and kayak up the slough. I suggest that you go in with the tide and leave before it goes out or you can be left in a sticky flat of mud for a while. Awesome views of birds, oyster beds and what I believe a pristine dune ecosystem. Be quiet and move slowly and you can get very close to the wildlife for some excellent photos. Be aware that there is a lot of private property areas surrounding the slough, so exit for a foray where it is allowed only.

properties.name: South Spit of The Eel's Mouth
properties.description: Posted by GordoWhere The Ocean Meets The EelThis bit of sand is where the Mighty Eel River meets the Big Blue Pacific and is a place where mighty waves, tidal surges, flood waters, salmon, steelhead, seals, seal lions, and about a gazillion birds come together.

properties.name: Spitsville
properties.description: Posted by GordoSouth end of the South Spit of Humboldt Bay. North Spit of the Mouth of the Mighty Eel RiverThis is where the mouth of the Eel River meets the South Spit of Humboldt Bay. Maybe it is the place where the southernmost part of the North Spit of the Eel river meets the southernmost spit of Humboldt Bay. The carcasses of 1000\'s of trees come to rest and look like some kind of elephants graveyard. and the flotsam and jetsam and litter of river and ocean come to rest. It is on this site that I caught the only fish I have ever hooked in my illustrious fishing career. (Four pathetic Red-Tailed Perch. Well, actually it is my fishing skills that are pathetic, not the fish.)

properties.name: Table Bluff
properties.description: Posted by GordoJust Below Table BluffGateway to such fine destinations as The mouth of the Eel River (See Spitsville) and the channel of Humboldt Bay (South Side) Great place to watch death-defying paragliders, hanggliders and the like leap with fabric wings from the cliff of the bluff above and soar (hopefully) out to the sun-dappled ocean and back to land gracefully(usually) on sandy shore or dune. pedestrians beware the sometimes inconsiderate or distracted ATV operators. A hit and a couple of near-misses has made me in to a VERY watchful individual.

properties.name: The Great Egret Nesting and Pooping Site of Gunther Island
properties.description: Posted by GordoThe Egret Aviary and Guano Depository of Gunther IslandA tall stand of trees ( I think they are Monterey Cypress) stand in the middle of Gunther Island (also less sensitively called "Indian Island", despite it being the site of a massacre of native people by local white citizens of Eureka.) One not so well moon-lit night Marta, Lorna, Steve, Dave and I paddled out in our kayaks and explored the island. When we went to look up at the birds, we were met by a fecal and urine shower. Some fun. I guess that we should have called ahead or atleast brought a gift or something. Later that same night we paddled across the island when the tide was so high that the majority of the island was submerged. Note to self: Bring umbrella next time.

properties.name: The Middle of South Bay
properties.description: Posted by GordoSouth BayThe middle of the South Bay of the Greater Humboldt Bay. Tides and currents can be strong here, and as Lorna, Steve, Dave, Marta, and I discovered one morning. When the wind whipped up 1 to 2 windwaves our kayaking trip turned in to a bit of a workout. The comparative stillness of the early morning spent paddling amongst curious and playful harbor seals was all but forgotten. Still, I would do it again.

properties.name: Woodley Island
properties.description: Posted by GordoWoodley Island Marina.Where so many of my day sailing trips (both with Nick, Eli, Marta, and alone) have begun and ended. A great place to walk and look at boats and watch seals and birds. Also a great place to look at Eureka\'s seamier side.
